docs.lead_paragraph: There is nothing in the Hippocratic Oath that tells doctors what to do when they make a mistake with a patient. Nor is there much on this subject in medical school curriculums or in residency training programs. But there should be.

headline.main: Learning Words They Rarely Teach in Medical School: 'I'm Sorry'

docs.snippet: There is nothing in the Hippocratic Oath that tells doctors what to do when they make a mistake with a patient. But there should be.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN you look back on all the attempts to curb teenage drinking, smoking and drug use over the last couple of decades, you start to ask yourself a question that countless parents have asked: Does anybody really know how to change a teenager's behavior? Sometimes the government and advocacy groups have used straight talk, like Nancy Reagan's ''Just Say No'' campaign. Other times they have tried to play it cool. They drop an egg into a sizzling frying pan and announce, ''This is your brain on drugs,'' or they print mock advertisements that pretend to market cancer. It all feels like a delicate exercise in adolescent psychology.

headline.main: To Reduce the Cost of Teenage Temptation, Why Not Just Raise the Price of Sin?

docs.abstract: David Leonhardt column says proven way to get teenagers to consume less alcohol, tobacco and drugs is to raise price, either by raising taxes on alcohol and tobacco or enacting zero-tolerance laws for young drivers; says such laws have added benefit of reducing unprotected sex, drunken-driving deaths and suicides among the young; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: How do you get teenagers to stop smoking? One solution is to hit them in the wallet.
